intro: Asperula oppositifolia subsp. cabulica, commonly known as the Kashmir bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves and clusters of small, bell-shaped white or pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving at elevations between 1,500 and 3,000 meters. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation efforts.
